choices.C: to expand the number of colors that are potentially applied to a network transport interface
choices.D: to aggregate multiple physical Interfaces into a single logical interface
choices.B: to identify the physical interface where a WAN Edge router connects to the WAN transport network
choices.A: to facilitate WAN Edge router redundancy within a site

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the types of WAN connectivity from the left onto the connectivity use cases on the right.

//IMG//

An engineer must design a management network for a customer's enterprise network. The design must:
• provide the ability to grant and revoke access privileges
• allow only protocols SSH, NTP, FTP, and SNMP
• restrict access to management interfaces

Which solution must the engineer choose to meet the requirements?

discussion.content:
Is it advisable to run this "allow only protocols SSH, NTP, FTP, and SNMP" in an out-of-band management? 

I think I'll go with in-band (A)
Basically you can limit the access in the in-band if you like

Hard to know

The Management Plane Protection (MPP) feature can be used to limit remote management sessions to specific trusted interfaces only. This is very useful when a router connects a trusted network to an untrusted network such as the Internet. MPP applies to all management protocols, such as SSH, HTTPS, and SNMP. This feature is configured using the management-interface command in the control pane. This command can be repeated to enable the same or a different set of protocols on other interfaces. One key restriction of this feature is that it cannot be applied to an out-of-band management interface (also called a dedicated management interface), if the device has one. Example 2-12 shows the usage of this command.
https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2928193&seqNum=2#:~:text=The%20Management%20Plane%20Protection%20(MPP,SSH%2C%20HTTPS%2C%20and%20SNMP.

Selected Answer: C
--> restrict access to management interfaces

Selected Answer: C
C. out-of-band

The engineer should choose an out-of-band management network solution to meet the customer's requirements. Out-of-band management involves using a separate, dedicated network for managing devices, separate from the production network. This approach provides the ability to grant and revoke access privileges, restrict access to management interfaces, and limit the allowed protocols to SSH, NTP, FTP, and SNMP. It also enhances security and control, as management traffic is isolated from the production traffic.

restrict access to management interfaces

questions.question_text: Which function do reverse path forwarding mechanisms perform in a multicast deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct. https://www.routeprotocol.com/reverse-path-forwarding-rpf/

questions.question_text: How does a model-driven telemetry dial-out approach function?

choices.B: The collector initiates a session to the device and subscribes to data to be streamed.
choices.C: The collector initiates a session to the device and gets the data of a previously defined subscription.
choices.A: The device initiates a session to the collector based on the subscription.
choices.D: The device initiates a session to the collector and negotiates a subscription.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. "With the TCP Dial-Out method, the router initiates a TCP session to the
collector and sends whatever data is specified by the sensor-group in the
subscription."

Reference: https://pubhub.devnetcloud.com/media/netdevops-live/site/files/s01t11.pdf
